content.raw:
A separate issue would be great! \(once migration happens\)

And if there is a chance, it would help us tremendously if there’s a way to somehow to connect to the person who directly had this issue \(might they have a public GitHub account so you can tag them when you make the issue?\).

If not, I understand!

\(It would also be nice to know explicitly how it manifested - e.g. is this just using solely `libsdformat` utilities, or is it through Gazebo Classic, Ignition Gazebo, etc…\)

pull_request.title: parse urdf files to sdf 1.5 instead of 1.4 to avoid use_parent_model_frame

pullrequest.title: parse urdf files to sdf 1.5 instead of 1.4 to avoid use_parent_model_frame

content.raw:
> And sorry to ask a dumb question, but exactly was the axis before, and what was it after? \(it’s not immediately apparent to me what “wrong axis” implies…\)  
> Could you post a complete \(but minimal\) repro of the issue, if possible?

To be honest I don’t know as I did not had access to the failing model. What I guess is that the “wrong axis” was the axis oriented as in the joint frame \(to comply with 1.5\) but that is interpreted as expressed in the model frame \(to comply with the parent 1.4 model\). As we now entered the freeze period of sdformat \(see [https://community.gazebosim.org/t/important-gazebo-and-ignition-are-going-to-github/533](https://community.gazebosim.org/t/important-gazebo-and-ignition-are-going-to-github/533)\) I can’t open an issue, but after that I can open a proper issue.
content.html:
And sorry to ask a dumb question, but exactly was the axis before, and what was it after? (it’s not immediately apparent to me what “wrong axis” implies…)
Could you post a complete (but minimal) repro of the issue, if possible?

To be honest I don’t know as I did not had access to the failing model. What I guess is that the “wrong axis” was the axis oriented as in the joint frame (to comply with 1.5) but that is interpreted as expressed in the model frame (to comply with the parent 1.4 model). As we now entered the freeze period of sdformat (see https://community.gazebosim.org/t/important-gazebo-and-ignition-are-going-to-github/533) I can’t open an issue, but after that I can open a proper issue.

pullrequest.title: parse urdf files to sdf 1.5 instead of 1.4 to avoid use_parent_model_frame

content.raw:
Thanks for the reply, unfortunately I don’t have a \[mwe\]\([https://stackoverflow.com/help/minimal-reproducible-example](https://stackoverflow.com/help/minimal-reproducible-example)\) as I learned about this from one of my colleagues working on a closed source project, and I just posted this as a note for people from the future that were debugging the same issue.  
In any case, for an example of a SDF that via  `<include>` loads a URDF file, you can see [https://github.com/robotology/icub-models/blob/master/fixed\_model.sdf.in](https://github.com/robotology/icub-models/blob/master/fixed_model.sdf.in) \(even if in that case everything works fine as the “parent” SDF is 1.5\). That is just a template, but if you build the project following the instructions in [https://github.com/robotology/icub-models](https://github.com/robotology/icub-models) you should get the installation prefix the actual  working example of an SDF model that includes a URDF model.
content.html:
Thanks for the reply, unfortunately I don’t have a [mwe](https://stackoverflow.com/help/minimal-reproducible-example) as I learned about this from one of my colleagues working on a closed source project, and I just posted this as a note for people from the future that were debugging the same issue.
In any case, for an example of a SDF that via <include> loads a URDF file, you can see https://github.com/robotology/icub-models/blob/master/fixed_model.sdf.in (even if in that case everything works fine as the “parent” SDF is 1.5). That is just a template, but if you build the project following the instructions in https://github.com/robotology/icub-models you should get the installation prefix the actual working example of an SDF model that includes a URDF model.

content.raw: I'm not aware of `<include>` being able to load URDF files. I found [this](http://gazebosim.org/tutorials/?tut=ros_roslaunch) tutorial that seems to indicate that it's possible. I gave it a quick try, but I couldn't get it to work. Do you have a working example?
content.html: I'm not aware of <include> being able to load URDF files. I found this tutorial that seems to indicate that it's possible. I gave it a quick try, but I couldn't get it to work. Do you have a working example?

pull_request.title: parse urdf files to sdf 1.5 instead of 1.4 to avoid use_parent_model_frame

pullrequest.title: parse urdf files to sdf 1.5 instead of 1.4 to avoid use_parent_model_frame

content.raw:
It is probably not super-important, but this PR apparently silently broke models in this form: 

‌

```xml
<?xml version='1.0'?>
<sdf version='1.4'>
  <model name="include_model_fixed">
    <include>
      <uri>model://include_model</uri>
      <pose>0.0 0 1.0 0 0 3.14</pose>
    </include>
    <joint name="fixed to ground" type="revolute">
      <parent>world</parent>
      <child>included_model::root_link</child>
       <axis>
        <limit>
          <lower>0</lower>
          <upper>0</upper>
        </limit>
        <xyz>0 0 1</xyz>
        </axis>
    </joint>
  </model>
</sdf>
```

This kind of  models now silently load the URDF with the wrong axis, while they were working correctly before. Fortunately the solution is easy, just  to update the version of the sdf model to 1.5, but it may be tricky to find the root of the problem.
content.html:
It is probably not super-important, but this PR apparently silently broke models in this form:

‌

<?xml version='1.0'?>
<sdf version='1.4'>
  <model name="include_model_fixed">
    <include>
      <uri>model://include_model</uri>
      <pose>0.0 0 1.0 0 0 3.14</pose>
    </include>
    <joint name="fixed to ground" type="revolute">
      <parent>world</parent>
      <child>included_model::root_link</child>
       <axis>
        <limit>
          <lower>0</lower>
          <upper>0</upper>
        </limit>
        <xyz>0 0 1</xyz>
        </axis>
    </joint>
  </model>
</sdf>

This kind of models now silently load the URDF with the wrong axis, while they were working correctly before. Fortunately the solution is easy, just to update the version of the sdf model to 1.5, but it may be tricky to find the root of the problem.

pull_request.title: parse urdf files to sdf 1.5 instead of 1.4 to avoid use_parent_model_frame

update.description: It's kind of annoying that `use_parent_model_frame` is set to true whenever we parse a urdf. This happens because they are converted to 1.4. Instead, just convert them to 1.5 and don't rotate the joint axis.
update.title: parse urdf files to sdf 1.5 instead of 1.4 to avoid use_parent_model_frame

content.raw: the `use_parent_model_frame` was added as a required element with a default of `true` in 1.4 and `false` in 1.5
content.html: the use_parent_model_frame was added as a required element with a default of true in 1.4 and false in 1.5
